SENT.plain: Carbamazepine has been used successfully in the treatment of different movement disorders and was recently reported to be effective for nonhereditary chorea
In view of the significant side effects associated with the drugs currently used to treat chorea, we sought to further evaluate the efficacy of carbamazepine in children with rheumatic chorea
The study was prospective and included 10 children with chorea (eight females and two males; age range = 7-16 years) referred to our Pediatric Rheumatology Clinic between 1995 and 1999
Nine had rheumatic fever and one had antiphospholipid antibody syndrome that later evolved to systemic lupus erythematosus
Improvement was evident within 2-14 days of initiation of low doses of carbamazepine (4-10 mg/kg daily)
The plasma drug levels were 2.8-8.2 microg/mL (therapeutic antiepileptic range = 8-12 microg/mL)
The duration of treatment was 1-15 months
Recurrence was observed in three patients who received a second trial of carbamazepine with a good response
We suggest that carbamazepine may serve as a first-line treatment for rheumatic chorea
